There is an in-line electrical resistance heated vaporizer on the outlet of the tank to ensure an adequate supply of gaseous ammonia during the colder winter months.  
The ammonia level (high and low) in the tank is electronically monitored both at a cabinet adjacent to the ammonia tank, in the station control room, and at the off-site monitoring center. Piping into the tank includes one fill line and two vapor return lines from loading station outside the containment wall, tank drain lines, and a supply line to the ammonia metering system.  
3.	A single supply line of approximately 2-inch inside diameter carries gaseous ammonia from the tank to the ammonia metering systems.  For a portion of the run of pipe, the supply line is above ground but protected from vehicles by metal bollards.  Individual take-off lines run from the supply line to the individual metering systems.  The nominal pressure of ammonia in the supply lines is approximately 2-3 inches of water.  The ammonia metering system consists of a pressure regulator, various valves, high and low pressure sensors, and the supply line to the injection ports on the individual turbine exhausts.  Once injected into the turbine exhaust, the ammonia is destroyed by chemical reaction with the exhaust to form water and elemental nitrogen, with a low parts per million (ppm) level of unreacted ammonia escaping from the exhaust stack as ammonia slip.

hanges to Improve Safety
Given the design and operational safeguards that are in-place, there are no current plans to upgrade the ammonia storage system for operational reasons.  Two improvements to safety relating to human factors during an ammonia unloading operation are being implemented at the facility.  First, when an ammonia delivery is in progress, a portable sign will be used warning visitors entering the facility that an ammonia unloading operation is taking place.  These signs will be placed at the facility entry gate.
Second, based on a recommendation from Kern County EHS during their last inspection, all facility staff will be issued cellular phone to allow ready communication between workers at the facility, the Taft facility, and the pipeline control room.  The cellular phones will be available for use by workers when an unloading operation or other major maintenance activities at the facility are in progress.  While workers are in visual contact with each other during unloading operations, the availability of the cellular phones provides a backup means for communication between staff during critical operations.

The Gas Company has prepared SOPs for the Wheeler Ridge Facility that contain detailed accident prevention and emergency response procedures including mandatory check lists, requirements for the cross checking of actions or operations, detailed operational steps, and procedures for upset conditions.  All operators undergo yearly training in emergency response to ammonia releases.  Additional training is also provided to some employees by the ammonia supplier, Argo Chemical Inc. Industries. 
The site is normally an unoccupied facility but is remotely monitored 24-hours per day from a company operations center.  An airborne release of ammonia from the ammonia storage tank will be detected by automatic ammonia detectors above the tank which will initiate the water deluge system, as well as initiate an alarm to the on-site control room and the 24-hour company monitoring center.  The response time for the on-call operator in nearby Taft once an alarm is triggered is approximately one hour or less.  Company personnel with responsibility for emergency response are assigned company vehicles and have two-way radios and cell phones.  In the event of loss of electrical power, an automatic emergency battery-powered electric pump will maintain pressure in the fire water loop until an operator arrives.  This loop, in addition to the 90,000 gallon fire water tank, supplies fire water to the facility and to the deluge system on the ammonia tank. 
An uninterruptable power supply (UPS) is on-site and will provide up to 8 hours of back-up power in the event of a power outage.  A backup diesel generator is on-site and can be started by the operator to provide station power in the event of electrical failure. The emergency fire water pump is designed for more than one hour of battery operation and so there would be no loss of water pressure in the extremely unlikely event of a simultaneous power failure and loss of water head from the 90,000-gallon fire water tank.

1.2	General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
1.2.1	Description of Stationary Source
The Gas Company operates the Wheeler Ridge natural gas pipeline compressor station near Wheeler Ridge in Kern County, California.  The North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 48621, Pipeline Transmission of Natural Gas.  The compressor station is located in an unpopulated agricultural area on the north side of State Highway 166 approximately 1.5 miles west of Interstate 5.  An anhydrous ammonia storage tank with a maximum capacity of 35,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is located on-site as part of an agency mandated Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) emission control system. Gaseous ammonia drawn from the vapor space of the tank is used for injection into the exhaust of three natural gas fired compressor turbines to control the emissions of nitrogen oxides into the atmosphere.  The ammonia system incorporates the ammonia tank, unloading equipment, ammonia vapor monitoring equipment, water deluge system, low-pressure piping to the ammonia metering system, and the ammonia metering system used to meter ammonia for injection into the compressor turbine exhaust.
Ammonia is delivered to the facility approximately six to eight times per year.  The storage tank is surrounded by a concrete containment structure able to contain the entire contents of the storage tank plus an allowance for precipitation or fire water.  The tank is protected by an automatic water deluge system fed by a 90,000 gallon fire water tank, a six-inch fire water loop around the entire facility, and an emergency

fire water pump with battery backup power.  The water deluge system produces 250 gallons per minute of water mist over the tank when activated.

Anhydrous ammonia is also regulated by the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) under 29 CFR Â§1910.119 in the Process Safety Management Program (PSM) if the on-site storage exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.  However, Normally unoccupied remote facilities are exempt from PSM under 29 CFR Â§1910.119 (a)(2)(iii).  Therefore, the Wheeler Ridge facility is exempted from PSM as it is a normally unoccupied remote facility. 

Consequently, the Wheeler Ridge facility falls under an RMP Program Level 2.  In Kern County, the Administrating Agency (AA) for an RMP plan is the Kern County Environmental Health Department.
The major hazards represented by the ammonia process are the accidental release of a toxic substance (ammonia) due to spill or rupture of the storage vessel, its associated piping system, and during a tanker truck unloading accident.  According to the hazard review conducted for this process the most probable accident scenario is the release of ammonia during an unloading incident. 
The land-use surrounding the facility is primarily agricultural.  There are several farm residences located within approximately one mile of the facility.  An interchange on Interstate 5 with State Route 166 is located approximately 1.5 miles east of the facility.  There are several businesses located adjacent to the interchange.
1.2.2	Description of the Process
There are three major steps in the handling of the ammonia from delivery to injection into the turbine exhaust.
1.	Anhydrous ammonia is received from the supplier by tanker truck.  The ammonia is purchased from a single supplier, Agro Chemical, Inc. Industries (Agro Chemical).    The tanker truck is not allowed to enter the facility until after the manifest and bill of lading are compared to the ordered amount of ammonia.  Once on the facility, t

he truck travels at low speed (5 miles per hour) directly to the unloading area, at which time it turns left and parks on the asphalt roadbed in front of the ammonia tank.  A gravel pad is on either side of the truck parking area.  Once at the unloading area, the truck is secured from movement using wheel chocks and hoses are hooked-up to the unloading station.  The truck engine has a safety interlock to prevent operation of the ignition when the truck is pumping.  In addition to the Agro Chemical operator, Gas Company personnel monitor the unloading from an upwind location. 
Unloading is accomplished using a pumping and vapor recovery system on the truck.  The specified load order from the truck is unloaded into the storage tank.  At the completion of loading, all residual liquid and vapors in the unloading hoses and piping are evacuated to the truck prior to disconnection of the hoses.  The ammonia tank is protected by a water deluge system during unloading.  In addition, a water cannon is approximately 15 m (50 ft) away if needed.  The deluge system and water cannon are supplied by a 90,000 gallon storage fire water system and 6 inch diameter fire water loop circling the facility.  Ammonia is ordered when the tank is approximately 30 percent full, with delivery when the tank is approximately 20 percent full.  Prior to filling, the level of ammonia in the tank is manually verified by a wipe-down of the side of the tank.  Unloading requires approximately 90 minutes.

The tank is a cylindrical tank mounted horizontally on two metal supports with concrete footings.  The tank is surrounded by a concrete containment structure (dike) with a capacity to contain the entire liquefied contents of the tank plus a 10 percent allowance for precipitation. The Southern California Gas Company (The Gas Company) maintains an anhydrous ammonia storage vessel and ancillary equipment at its Wheeler Ridge Compressor Station near Wheeler Ridge in Kern County, California. The maximum capacity of the tank is 35,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The facility is subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions of 40 CFR Â§68 because the potential amount of ammonia on-site exceeds the threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 pounds defined in Â§68.130. The facility falls under the provisions of RMP Program Level 2 as it is a normally unoccupied facility.  However, it is remotely monitored 24-hours per day from a company operations center.
A hazard review conducted for the 5 year update concluded that the existing safety systems, procedures, and administrative controls that are in place to prevent an accidental release of ammonia provide acceptable mitigation for potential accidental release scenarios.  A seismic review update concluded that the ammonia tank and containment structure are adequately constructed and maintained to provide adequate seismic capacity in the event of planning level earthquake under the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program.
